text.headline: Story1: education
text.text: 1. Introduction and background: Shamim represents the 9.4 per cent of girls in Kampala between aged 12-17 years who have given birth. (Source: Census 2014: Equity Analysis). Shamim is a mother to a 6 months old baby girl. When her guardians learned that she was pregnant, they sent her away from home and so Shamim and her baby came to stay with 2 other roommates in a one roomed house in Katanga, one of the slums in Kampala. (Source: Emerging Global Challenges Report, UNICEF, 2017). Shamim works as a full time apprentice at a saloon in Kampala

text.headline: 5:30am
text.text: Shamim wakes up to clean the house and to prepare breakfast before her baby wakes. She then has breakfast, usually porridge made from maize flour. Shamim has problems in accessing clean education, as she does not have enough money to buy it from the public pipes. Today she is lucky as a pipe in the neighbourhood has broken, and she has a chance to get some education for free. After she returns from collecting education, she wakes up the baby, gives her a bath, feeds her and dresses her up and then plays with her for a short while. Shamim packs her baby’s immunization card in her bag and the baby’s extra clothes in a polythene bag, as it is the day for the baby’s routine immunization at 6 months.

text.headline: 11:30 p.m
text.text: She wishes she could go back to school or get some vocational training to be able to get a better job in the future, such as starting a small business, like a hair salon of her own. (Source: Urban CSSP Focus Group Discussions, 2018.)

text.headline: 1:00 p.m
text.text: Shamim’s baby starts to cry of hunger, but Shamim is unable to breastfeed her, because she herself has not eaten well and is therefore having difficulties in producing milk. Shamim gives the baby some of the leftovers of her workmates’ lunch.

text.headline: 8:00p.m
text.text: Shamim ties her baby to the back and walks home. It is a long walk home but since she needs to save the money that she made as a salary and from the tips given by kind customers, she has to walk home.

text.headline: Ask CHL
text.text:
If you know a child or an adolescent in this situation or in other dangerous situation, please advise them to call the child helpline, or contact the helpline yourself.
